The direct formation of saturated branched ketones from primary alcohols and butadiene in the absence of premetalated intermediates or other hydrogen sources is a mechanistically intriguing transformation. Catalyzed by a rhodium(I) catalyst (Rh(COD)2BArF 4/PPh3) under basic conditions, this reaction proceeds with moderate to high experimental yields. Applying density functional theory, we investigate the mechanism of the conversion of 3-methoxybenzyl alcohol and butadiene into (branched) isobutyl ketone. This reaction involves four key steps: (i) oxidation of the alcohol to the corresponding aldehyde, with the generation of an Rh(I) hydride complex as an active catalyst, (ii) hydrogenation of butadiene to form an allyl–Rh(I) complex, (iii) carbonyl addition from the allylic carbon, forming an Rh(I) alkoxide intermediate, and (iv) an intramolecular hydrogen-transfer processes to generate the desired ketone product. The rate-determining states correspond to the carbonyl addition, involving both the intermediate and transition states, with an energy barrier of +30.4 kcal/mol. We found that two PPh3 ligands are coordinated to the Rh center throughout the reaction. Therefore, carbonyl addition to the linear ketone is inhibited by steric hindrance around the metal center. Stereoisomerism among intermediates has a negligible effect on the reaction energetics and does not affect the configuration of the final product, which is released in an enolate form. Calculated positions of the transferred hydrogens align with the experimental deuterium labeling results, highlighting a hydrogen (auto)transfer mechanism in the transformation of primary alcohols to branched ketones. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Branched ketone production Enolate-ketone production Hydrogen transfer Carbonyl addition Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Recent ketones synthesis methods—oxidation of alcohols or organic halides, [1,2] alkylation of alcohols, [3] carbonyl addition to aldehydes, [4] fabrication from carboxylic acids and their derivatives, [5–7] and various others, [8–11] typically require pre-metalation steps or structurally complex starting materials. Consequently, the development of direct and operationally simple synthesis methods for ketones and their derivatives remains a highly desirable goal in organic synthesis [12]. In this context, Krische’s group has developed a class of hydrogen-transfer processes (“borrowing hydrogen” processes) for synthesizing ketones and other value-added commercial products [13–17]. During the hydrogen-transfer process, a metal catalyst borrows a hydrogen atom from the oxidized alcohol and subsequently returns the hydrogen to form the final product [18–21]. Expanding on this concept, the hydrogen-transfer process enables carbonyl addition and hydrogenation uses alcohols (reagents) as hydrogen sources, facilitating C−C bond formation [21–26]. As an example of the hydrogen (auto)transfer process, Scheme 1 a shows the conversion of primary alcohols and butadiene into branched ketones, catalyzed by a rhodium (Rh) complex [14]. The ketones are fabricated via C−C bond formation between the CC O of alcohol and the C2 of butadiene, followed by hydrogenation of the butadiene adduct to form the butane fragment. This ketone synthesis requires no premetalated reagents or multistep protocols and is highly selective, forming only branched products in high yields. The deuterium labeling experiment, which traces the hydrogen/deuterium positions in the final product, suggests the occurrence of hydrogenerative carbonyl addition via the hydrogen autotransfer process. Deuterium is located at (or around) the hydrogenation site (Scheme 1b). Moreover, when two types of alcohols (one labeled with deuterium and another unlabeled) are added into the same reaction (the so-called double-labeling cross-over experiment), no deuterium cross-over products are observed, implying that the catalyst/reagents do not dissociate as the hydrogen/deuterium moves from the reagents to product generation. Hence, Krische and coworkers proposed a general mechanistic cycle with Rh(I) hydride as the active catalyst [14]. To clarify the catalytic reaction cycle, we elucidate the mechanistic profiles of the conversion of 3-methoxybenzyl alcohol (A) and butadiene into isobutyl ketone (C) through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. We explain the reaction processes, describe the origin of product selectivity, and justify the hydrogen/deuterium positions and zero cross-over products. Our results are intended to provide an understanding of the nature of this reaction and to guide future developments in ketone and carbonyl compound synthesis. Computational details All DFT calculations were performed using the Gaussian16 program [27]. The geometries of all species were optimized using the PBE0 [28]-D3 [29–31] functional with the LANL2DZ effective core potential [32,33] for the Rh atom and the 6–31+G(d) basis set [34–38] for other atoms in the gas phase. Single-point calculations were computed using the SMD implicit solvation model, [39] combining the PBE0-D3 functional with the LANL2DZ effective core potential for the Rh atom and the 6–31++G(d,p) basis set for other atoms in chlorobenzene solvent. The PBE0-D3 functional was selected for its excellent computation of the Rh complexes thermochemistry [40]. The “ultrafine” integration grid was used to prevent errors arising from the lack of rotational invariance in the computed free energies [41]. Analysis of vibrational frequencies ensured that each structure was either a local minimum (zero imaginary frequency) or a transition state (one imaginary frequency) on the potential energy surface. The connectivity of each transition states to the corresponding reactant and product was confirmed by calculating the intrinsic reaction coordinates (IRC). The free energies, including the solvation-corrected PBE0-D3 electronic energies and the corrected thermal and free energies in the gas phase, are reported under standard conditions (25 °C, 1 atm). The relative free energies at the reaction temperature (130 °C) are listed in the Supplementary materials (Table S1). Results and discussion The conversion of alcohol A and butadiene to isobutyl ketone C, initially proposed by Krische and coworkers, is refined into a catalytic cycle with four main steps: (i) oxidation of alcohol A (in the form of alkoxide A– ), generating a corresponding aldehyde B, and an Rh(I) hydride complex (Scheme 2 ), (ii) coordination of butadiene to the catalyst, forming an allyl–Rh(I) complex that rebinds the aldehyde, rendering (iii) carbonyl addition to form the Rh(I) alkoxide intermediate, and (iv) β-hydride elimination and hydrogen-transfer steps to obtain the enolate product (C– ). Liberation of C– and exchange of C– with the starting alkoxide A– regenerates the Rh(I) alkoxide complex and concludes the catalytic cycle. After elucidating the reference state and the formation of active catalysts via alcohol oxidation, we explain each step of the proposed mechanism. Finally, we summarize our findings and compare them with the experimental evidence. Reference-state complexes and formation of the active catalyst The conversion of 3-methoxybenzyl alcohol (A) and butadiene to the branched ketone C was catalyzed by an Rh complex formed using a pre-catalyst (Rh(COD)2BArF 4, 5 mol%), triphenylphosphine (PPh3, 11 mol%), and K2CO3 (50 mol%) in a chlorobenzene solvent (Scheme 1a). The starting catalyst was traditionally proposed as RhI(PPh3)2 coordinated with the BArF 4 counter-ion or a KCO3 – base, but the cyclooctadiene (COD) ligand is now known to coordinate to the metal center in starting complexes [42–44]. Hence, we computed various candidate Rh catalysts and selected the most feasible one as the reference state. Note that we omitted the counter-anion from the Rh(I) complexes to simplify the calculation. This omission might affect the reactivity of cationic catalysts, [45–47] but should not affect the stability of our reaction because the Rh complexes are neutral throughout the catalytic cycle. Starting with [RhI(COD)2]+, one COD can be exchanged with one PPh3 ligand to form [RhI(COD)PPh3]+. The free energy of this complex exceeds that of [RhI(COD)2]+ by 6.8 kcal/mol. After adding another PPh3 ligand, the more stable [RhI(COD)(PPh3)2]+ complex with a 6.6 kcal/mol lower free energy than [RhI(COD)2]+ is formed (Scheme 3 a). Formation of [RhI(PPh3)2]+ via dissociation of the COD ligand from [RhI(COD)(PPh3)2]+ is energetically unfavorable, likely because [RhI(PPh3)2]+ has insufficient number of coordinated ligands and is unstable. To illustrate the effect of ion stability, we coordinated Rh(I) hydride complexes with COD and PPh3 ligands (Scheme 3b). The incoming hydride stabilizes the Rh(I) complex; for example, relative to the [RhI(COD)2]+ complex, the free energies of [RhI(COD)(PPh3)]+ is +6.8 kcal/mol, while RhI(COD)(PPh3)H is 14.4 kcal/mol lower than RhI(COD)H. Nevertheless, the most stable species are [RhI(COD)(PPh3)2]+ and RhI(COD)(PPh3)H, implying that stable Rh complexes require sufficient ligand coordination. We now consider the formation of the Rh(I) hydride complex, starting from the most stable cationic species [RhI(COD)(PPh3)2]+ (denoted as complex 1) as the reference state and the reactants, comparing the relative free energies of each step. Potassium carbonate can abstract a proton from alcohol A, generating an alkoxide ion (A– ) [48] that can bind to the starting catalyst via exchange with a COD ligand to form complex 2 or via exchange with PPh3 to form complex 2′ (Scheme 4 ). Both 2 and 2′ can undergo β-hydride elimination to generate Rh(I) hydride complexes 3 and 3′, respectively, in which having aldehyde B coordinates with the Rh center via a carbonyl bond. The transition states of this process (TS2–3 and TS2′–3′) require energies of +3.4 and +21.5 kcal/mol, respectively. Complex 2′ with a higher coordination number than complex 2 is more stable because its COD ligand can coordinate with the Rh center via its two double bonds, although the structures and relative free energies of their corresponding transition states are quite similar (Fig. 1 ). We hereafter select the Rh complex with the PPh3 ligand as the candidate active catalyst. Then, one PPh3 ligand or aldehyde B dissociates from 3 to generate intermediate 4A or 4L, which serve as precursors for hydride-ligand transfer to butadiene in the next step. Hydrogenation of butadiene The three-coordinated Rh(I) hydride complexes 4A (where A denotes aldehyde) and 4L (where L denotes the PPh3 ligand) differ at one coordination site. Butadiene can bind to the 4A and 4L complexes via one of its double bonds (C1 C2), generating 5A and 5L, respectively (Scheme 5 ). As the butadiene conformations might affect the stability of the transition states, we considered the pathways of both the cis (-c) and trans (-tr) configurations of butene product fragments. The energy difference between the two butadiene conformations of intermediate 5 is ∼3–5 kcal/mol. In the following relative free energy computations of all pathways, s-trans butadiene is assumed as the starting compound. Adding butadiene to 4L helps to stabilize both conformations of 5L. Butadiene is then effortlessly hydrogenated to produce the very stable η3-allyl–Rh(I) complexes 6L. The transition states TS5L–6L-c and TS5L–6L-tr possess similar energies because they do not involve the other double bond (C3 C4) of butadiene and the C1–H, Rh–H, and Rh–C1 bond distances in both transition states are similar (Fig. 2 ). In contrast, butadiene addition and hydrogenation of 4A are uphill processes. The formation of the cis- and trans-conformations of TS5A–6A must overcome energies of +10.7 and +5.2 kcal/mol, respectively. The higher energy of the cis-transition state than the trans-structure (+5.5 kcal/mol) is attributable to differences in shape and coordination number: the coordination of the C3 C4 double bond to the metal center lengthens the Rh–H and Rh–C1 bond distances, reducing the stability of the transition state. We also computed the hydrogenation process with the mono(phosphine)–Rh(I) complex (from complex 5 as Rh(PPh3)H(butadiene)). The required energies reach or exceed that of TS5A–6A (Scheme S1 and Fig. S1) indicating that butadiene hydrogenation favors the L pathways with two PPh3 coordinated ligands on the metal complexes. Carbonyl addition and hydrogen transfer Aldehyde B, formed after generating active Rh(I) hydride complex 3, rebinds to the metal catalyst as complex 6AL prior to carbonyl addition. Once coordinated with Rh through its lone electron pair on oxygen, butenyl changes its hapticity from η3 to η1 providing space for the aldehyde while retaining the square planar geometry of the complex (Fig. 3 ). Carbonyl addition occurs via two possible pathways: attack of CC O of B by the C2 of butenyl fragment, which yields a branched ketone, and addition via C4 to obtain a linear product. The latter has not been experimentally observed [14]. Carbonyl addition to form branched ketones occurs via TS6AL–7L-c or TS6AL–7L-tr, which have similar free energies (−14 kcal/mol relative to the reference state; see Scheme 6 ). The energies of the TS6AL–7L-c or TS6AL–7L-tr transition states are +30.4 and +31.6 kcal/mol from those of the cis- and trans-configurations of 6L, respectively. Despite their similar energies, the resulting stereoisomer of alkoxide fragments is unique in intermediate 7L. Once the butenyl carbon attacks the carbonyl, it generates a stereocenter at both the carbonyl (S- only) and the attacker carbon of butenyl (C2) (denoted as Cα in intermediate 7L). A carbon at the alpha position (Cα) adopts the S-configuration if the reaction proceeds via the cis-transition state (TS6AL–7L-c), but the trans-structure TS6AL–7L-tr delivers R-alkoxide. The formation of stereo-carbon is illustrated in Fig. 3. To fully understand whether the conformation of reactants and species in the catalytic cycle non-negligibly influences the reaction steps, we explored all possible pathways corresponding to chiral centers and stereoisomers in all species. Note that although the alkoxide/ketone fragments in the intermediates are chiral, the final product is not stereoselective because it dissociates from the Rh catalyst as an enolate. When the C4 of butenyl attacks the carbonyl carbon, the transition states of the linear product, TS6AL–7L′-c and TS6AL–7L′-tr, are formed (red line, Scheme 6). These transition states exhibit high relative free energies, approximately 14 and 44 kcal/mol, higher, respectively, than those of the branched ketone TS and the intermediate 6L. Both optimized structures of the carbonyl addition transition states (Fig. 3) exhibit a twisted boat-like structure, but the position of Rh in the twisted boat are different. Formation of linear products requires additional space in the transition cycle because the CH3 of butenyl remains close to the metal center. However, with two bulky PPh3 ligands coordinated to Rh, the square planar geometry is not easily maintained, and the linear transition state assumes a tetrahedral shape (Fig. S2). The moderately high relative free energies of TS6AL–7L′ disfavor the linear product pathways. As the branched alkoxide via TS6AL–7L is more easily formed than the linear product, we expect a similar situation for carbonyl addition to mono(phosphine)–Rh complexes. Judging from the relative free energies of the computed transition states with one PPh3 ligand (Scheme S2), linear alkoxide formation actually requires less energy than the branched transition states but neither formation is feasible (the formation energies of the cis-transition states of the branched and linear products are +55.2 and +45.7 kcal/mol, respectively, relative to 6L-c). Both transition states possess a six-membered ring structure but with different conformation: linear TS6A–7′ is a twisted boat with a double butenyl bond coordinated to the metal center, whereas branched TS6A–7 is a boat form in which only the terminal carbon of the allylic fragment coordinates to Rh (Fig S3). Clearly, the coordination number crucially influences the stabilization of Rh complexes and their transition states. Carbonyl addition via TS6AL–7L leads to two possible forms (S- and R-configurations at Cα) of the Rh(I) alkoxide 7L. The β-hydride is then eliminated via TS7L–8. The hydrogen of the carbonyl transfers to Rh and the ketone adduct coordinates to the metal center via the Cβ=Cγ double bond, forming intermediate 8. The chiral center remains unchanged (Scheme 7 and Fig. 4 ). The hydride then transfers to the carbon terminal (Cγ) of ketone via TS8–9, creating another chiral center at Cβ. Hence, there are four transition states corresponding to each stereoisomer: RR, RS, SS, and SR with relative free energies ranging from −31.3 to −24.2 kcal/mol (differing by ∼7 kcal/mol). The stabilities of their products (intermediate 9) differ by ∼4 kcal/mol. Interestingly, although the TS8–9-RR transition state requires the highest energy among the four stereomers, its corresponding intermediate 9-RR is the most stable species. However, as the energy differences are very small, all conformations of TS8–9 and intermediate 9 are feasible. During the next step, hydrogen is transferred from the chiral Cα of the ketone to the metal center. After losing a hydrogen to Rh, Cα forms a double bond with Cβ. After the β-hydride elimination transition state TS9–10, intermediate 10 adopts the cis- or trans-configuration (Scheme 7). The hydride can return to Cβ of the ketone via TS10–11 and the ketone adduct then coordinates to the metal center in η3-fashion, as in intermediate 11. All pathways merge into 11, from which the ketone product dissociates in enolate form (under basic conditions) and exchanges with the starting alkoxide A– to regenerate intermediate 2 and close the catalytic cycle. All β-hydride elimination and hydrogen-transfer processes are relatively facile; the most difficult step being 10→TS10–11 with an energy gap of +17.5 kcal/mol for the cis-isomer. Overall catalytic cycle and other pathways According to our findings, the conversion of A and butadiene into branched ketone C proceeds through four main steps: (i) oxidation of alcohol A (in the form of alkoxide A– ), generating the corresponding aldehyde B and the active catalyst 4L, (ii) butadiene hydrogenation to form the allyl−Rh(I) complex 6L, (iii) carbonyl addition from the allylic carbon to produce the Rh(I) alkoxide intermediate 7L, and (iv) hydrogen-transfer processes that generate the desired ketone product and regenerate complex 2 (Scheme 2). Calculating the rate-determining states based on the energetic span model, [49–51] which are more accurate than the rate-determining step based on rate kinetic, we found that the turnover-determining transition state (TDTS) is TS6AL–7L and turnover-determining intermediate (TDI) is 6L, both are in carbonyl addition process; its energy gap is +30.4 kcal/mol for cis-configuration. Note that although intermediate 11 is the most stable species in the cycle (−48.0 kcal/mol), it is preceded by the transition state TS6AL–7L, so the activation energy calculation would need to consider the total reaction energy term, thus reducing the energy span number. When considering the experimental temperature (130 °C), the energy barrier of the rate-determining states is +35.4 kcal/mol for cis-configuration. Considering the stereomers of all species in the catalytic cycle, we found that configuration exerts an unimportant effect on the stabilities of the catalysts in all steps and does not influence the stereomers of the final product, which is dissociated in enolate form and abstracts a proton from the solution during the work-up step. Therefore, the expected product is a mixture. To determine other possible pathways, we calculated a mechanism in which alcohol A (instead of aldehyde B) binds to the allyl−Rh(I) complex 6L via exchange with one PPh3 ligand (Scheme S3). In this pathway, the alcohol should be converted to an aldehyde through β-hydride elimination. The hydride will then transfer to C3 of the butenyl fragment via TSB1–B2 prior to carbonyl addition. This process requires an excess energy of +39.5 kcal/mol (from that of B2) to overcome its corresponding transition state (TSB2–B3). The process is unattainable because the butadiene fragment is fully hydrogenated with no electronic stabilization from a π-bond, resulting in a four-membered ring transition state. Hence, the lack of allylic character in the transition states prevents the carbonyl addition process. Alignments across experimental observations Deuterium labeling experiments reveal the hydrogen positions of alcohol A in the ketone product C (Scheme 1b), illustrating that primary alcohol is another hydrogen source of butadiene hydrogenation [14]. Labeled hydrogen/deuterium atoms are found at the Hβ, Hγ, and HMe positions; no deuterium is observed at the Hα position. Our studies indicate the initial transfer of one hydrogen from A to butadiene, generating a butenyl fragment via TS5L–6L. After the following carbonyl addition process, this hydrogen becomes HMe (pink hydrogen atom in Fig. 3). Another hydrogen from A transfers to C during the β-hydride elimination and hydrogen-transfer process. We demonstrated that this hydrogen is attached to the Cγ position, becoming Hγ (green hydrogen atom in Fig. 4). Hydrogen/deuterium can also be found at the Hβ position because other hydride shifting processes in the reaction are possible [52–56]. Consistent with the lack of deuterium at the alpha position, our mechanism predicts that the product is dissociated as the enolate form, in which Cα forms a double bond with CC O ; hence, the hydrogen binding to Cα can be a proton or hydrogen from the separation or work-up step. In a cross-over experiment with two alcohols (D and E) in the reaction, no hydrogen/deuterium cross-over is observed in the products (Scheme 1b). In our mechanistic cycle, each alcohol should bind to the metal catalyst as described for intermediate 7L, undergoing facile hydrogen-transfer processes until the products are liberated. Once the reactant binds to the catalyst, it should easily convert to the ketone without dissociation of the reactant during hydrogen-transfer. Thus, no cross-over product should be observed. If the alcohol reactant is replaced with an aldehyde, the reaction can occur only in the presence of sodium formate [14]. This finding is also explained by our reaction mechanism, which requires alcohol reactants to generate the Rh(I) hydride complex 4L, that binds to butadiene and undergoes hydrogenation. If alcohol is absent in the system, the Rh(I) hydride complex cannot form through this pathway. Another hydrogen source, such as sodium formate, can provide an alternative pathway for generating the active catalyst 4L. We showed that the Rh(I) complex, a typical catalyst of hydroformylation, hydrosilylation, and acrylation, [57–60] can well catalyze hydrogenation and hydrogen-transfer processes. We suggest that the most difficult step in this reaction (carbonyl addition), can be facilitated by reactants with an electron-donating group substituted on butadiene to improve that carbonyl-attacking ability of C2. Electron-withdrawing groups on primary alcohols would also accelerate this step. However, as excessively bulky reactants would prevent the reaction, the electronic and steric factors of the reactants must be carefully balanced to increase the productivity. Conclusion 3-Methoxybenzyl alcohol and butadiene are converted into a branched ketone (C) through four main steps: alcohol oxidation, butadiene hydrogenation, carbonyl addition, and hydrogen-transfer. Carbonyl addition is the most difficult step with an energy barrier of +30.4 kcal/mol. Only branched ketones are observed because the carbonyl addition leading to linear products is energetically disfavored. Surveying the stereomers of the reactions, we found no obvious stereo-effects on the structures and relative free energies corresponding to their intermediate and transition states. In addition, the configuration of the reactant fragments did not affect the product selectivity because the product is released in an enolate form, which explains the experimentally observed absence of hydrogen/deuterium at the Cα position. coredata.dc:description: The direct formation of saturated branched ketones from primary alcohols and butadiene in the absence of premetalated intermediates or other hydrogen sources is a mechanistically intriguing transformation. Catalyzed by a rhodium(I) catalyst (Rh(COD)2BArF 4/PPh3) under basic conditions, this reaction proceeds with moderate to high experimental yields. Applying density functional theory, we investigate the mechanism of the conversion of 3-methoxybenzyl alcohol and butadiene into (branched) isobutyl ketone. This reaction involves four key steps: (i) oxidation of the alcohol to the corresponding aldehyde, with the generation of an Rh(I) hydride complex as an active catalyst, (ii) hydrogenation of butadiene to form an allyl–Rh(I) complex, (iii) carbonyl addition from the allylic carbon, forming an Rh(I) alkoxide intermediate, and (iv) an intramolecular hydrogen-transfer processes to generate the desired ketone product. The rate-determining states correspond to the carbonyl addition, involving both the intermediate and transition states, with an energy barrier of +30.4 kcal/mol. We found that two PPh3 ligands are coordinated to the Rh center throughout the reaction. Therefore, carbonyl addition to the linear ketone is inhibited by steric hindrance around the metal center. Stereoisomerism among intermediates has a negligible effect on the reaction energetics and does not affect the configuration of the final product, which is released in an enolate form. Calculated positions of the transferred hydrogens align with the experimental deuterium labeling results, highlighting a hydrogen (auto)transfer mechanism in the transformation of primary alcohols to branched ketones.
